For not knowing 22k to 24k miles is quite a good guess ^^

Anyway - you probably can only use the actual circumference of the equator mostly - maybe stretch this a bit, yes (factor of 2, maybe 5 or so) by partly "stacking" them. Problem is though: If you set them of a bit to north or south at some point they will cross the equator go up the same distance to the north - basically crossing the path were you aligned all the other geostationary satellites. Same if you stack them in different heights: Since you want an orbit to take 24 hours, you might go lower on one side of the orbit, but you have to go higher than geostationary on the other side.
You could work around this probably by setting apogee and perigee at above the equator (in essence crossing the equatorial plane at a "distance" to geostationary orbit) and do cross the geostationary distance "above" or "below" the equator. But this will probably have it's limits, since the position of the satellite will slightly deviate.
But well... with carefull planning you might even stack more satellites in the near geostationary zone than one could expect. You are only limited by some positional mismatch, due to the elliptical orbit (in essence making the satellite move right and left as seen from the ground) and tilting your orbit a bit (making the sattelite move up and down as seen from ground).

What makes a Tim Dodd launch live hosting session the best way to watch a launch? Tim Dodd knows when to shut up! I remember the old days Walter Cronkite would be filling every millisecond of time with his voice while capsule communications went on in the background and I struggled to unlisten to Cronkite to hear what was going on.

Tim always respects the fact that the event is king, and he just adds to that event. When I watch a live feed I won't miss anything that's being said by SpaceX's great broadcast crew, plus I get all the tidbits that Tim brings to the table too. Rather than replacing the launch with commentary, Tim reinforces and adds to the experience, both a humble thing to do and bringing enthusiasm to events that normally wouldn't even be noticed by normal people.

Thanks Tim!
TMRO is the worst!! They think human Mars flight have to be 100 percent perfect in order to happen!

No, you can't stagger and be geosynchronous.  Period.  Newton's laws and stuff.  The limits on how many have nothing to do with "fitting" but with ground station antenna beamwidth and pointing accuracy (which would be made worse from orbital wobble if staggering were done, or drift if any other altitude used, this is REALLY BASIC).  Now, if they all use different frequency bands for comm...you can have them closer to a point, but there's a limit to that too - signals need bandwidth to be useful at non zero data rates, and receiver desensing is an issue.  You can't go too low in frequency as the antenna on the bird gets too big, or too high because we don't have the tech for that yet (and at some point, the air and weather eat your signal).

Stars spin around us once per sidereal day, Dodd.
Geostationary satellites don't spin around us at all.
To stay in place in our sky, stars would have to move at absolutely ridiculous speeds, and in a curve that's not held in place by gravity, so they'd have to be constantly accelerated by some kind of centripetal force.
Be more careful with your comparisons, people look up to you and might believe something you say in error.

The single biggest DISADVANTAGE of air launching is there is a limit to how big the air launched rocket can be - and that, of course, limits the payload. Up to now, Orbital ATK have used their Pegasus launcher in conjunction with initially NASA's old B-52 and in more recent years with a Lockheed L1011 Tristar.
Virgin are designing an air launch system using an ex-Virgin Atlantic 747.
And there is Stratolauncher
